public void run() {
    StringBuilder input = new StringBuilder();
    try {
        int data;
        while (!isInterrupted()) {
            while ((data = in.read()) != -1 && !isInterrupted()) {
                input.append(Integer.toHexString(data));
                if (data == 's' || data == 'r' || data == 'w') {
                    handleInput(input.toString());
                    input = new StringBuilder();
                }
            }
            try {
                sleep(500);
            } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                break;
            }
        }
        socket.close();
    } catch (IOException e) {
        main.log("Connection lost...");
        main.log(e.toString());
        main.stopBTCommunication();
        main.startBTServer();
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: The InputStream.read() method reads the next byte of data from the input stream. The value byte is returned as an int in the range 0 to 255. If no byte is available because the end of the stream has been reached, the value -1 is returned. This method blocks until input data is available, the end of the stream is detected, or an exception is thrown. In your case, you are reading each byte individually and appending it to a string. You then check if the byte is a command ('s', 'r', or 'w'), and if it is, you handle the input and clear the string for the next command. This allows you to handle multiple commands in one line.
